bibl.title: Letter from Harold W. Jones to Philip Showalter Hench, February 17, 1942

div1.p: Jones informs Hench that his journal would not be interested in publishing Hench's article on the Cuban version of the Cornwell painting.

div1.head: Letter from Harold W. Jones to Philip Showalter Hench, February 17, 1942
div1.opener:

Associate Editor

Washington, D. C.
MISS L. MARGUERIETE PRIME

MISS RUTH HARLAMERY
King County Medical Society Library

MEDICAL LIBRARY ASSOCIATION

MEDICAL LIBRARY ASSOCIATION
FOUNDED 1902
Office of the Editor
Army Medical Library
7th Street and Independence Ave., S. W.
Washington, D. C.
February 17, 1942.
Dr. P.S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Your letter of February 12 has just been received and I
was intending to answer it as soon as I received the reprint of the
Yellow Fever story which you say you have sent by separate post.
Just today my secretary discovered a paper which you left here
entitled “Conquerors of Yellow Fever” which is illustrated by
Dean Cornwell. We have a full-sized copy which John Weyth Company
sent us framed. I am very glad to have your reprint.

Referring to your very kind offer of publishing one or two
of the Cuban versions of the painting, I doubt the advisability of
our attempting to do this. In the first place, the imagination has
to be drawn on pretty well to vision anything like the paintings and
I do not feel that we would be serving any useful purpose as a
library journal, to publish what the Cubans believe and would have us
believe, that Finlay should occupy the center of the stage (a somewhat
make-believe one) and not Reed. If we were to attempt this, I am
confident that I would come in for adverse criticism as the Editor of
an American library journal. So you see I took the opportunity of
being frank as you asked me to be! However, anyone who can write as
well as you do, could write something else for us and I hope you will
feel in the mood for this some time.

I am returning your colored pictures as you requested, and
thank you again. I am sorry I was ill when you called.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Harold W. Jones
Editor ADDRESS ALL COMMUNICATIONS TO THE EDITOR
